A Midsummer Night's Dream

Slapstick humour and outlandish costumes make this adaptation one for the kids, but the director sacrifices any real resemblance to the original text

Grimm Tales

Observing the female nude through a lens of aesthetic appreciation, this is subtle blend between fairytale and the beauty of the human body

The House of Bernada Alba

Two superb hours of almost claustrophobic familiarity, set in the hidden world of spanish women pre-civil war

The Rum Diary

A mix of the surreal and the sublime, the rum dairy is another presentation of Johnny Depp's ability to play the unusual, complicated and ultimately thought provoking character

Scooped

A primary colour theme, but delivered with first-class style.

By James Bithell

This production of Tennessee Williams' stark and highly poetic one-act play is impressive, yet displayed regrettable moments of weakness.

By James Bithell

By James Bithell

Future Sounds: Jonti

A blend of woozy loops and layers of sickly-sweet production make an impressive, if exhausting, listen. (Thumbnail credit Jonti)

Waiting for Godot

By James Bithell

For a play in which, infamously, 'nothing happens, twice', this compelling and darkly comic piece passed astonishingly quickly.

Smashing Pumpkins

Corgan's voice in recent years has often veered into a nasally whine that spoils some of the Pumpkins' older songs, tonight it sounds as ethereal as it did on those early albums. (Thumbnail credit Photo credit: Andra Veraat)

Al Murray: An Interview

By James Bithell

Pint-pulling comedian Al Murray talks to James Harle about getting political, the importance of history, and the joys of being a student.

The Good, The Bad, and The Queen

The Good, The Bad, and The Queen differs from your run of the mill supergroup. (Thumbnail credit The Good The Bad and The Queen)

Unknown Ritual

The Norman Rea Gallery's new exhibition blends ancient myth and human calamity to explain the phenomenon of ritual, and to ultimately question: What is death? What comes after it?

Our National Treasure

After a summer of 'wedding fever', the Royal Collection has been given a re-vamp. With the Queen's Diamond Jubilee approaching in 2012, what new artistic direction will the Collection take to celebrate it?

Leeds International Film Festival: L'Enfer

'Inferno' is reminiscent of the best French cinema. Rarely predictable, it seamlessly connects the torment of three individuals; sometimes overdramatic and contrived, but always elegant and thought-provoking.

The Movements: Postmodernism

The exhibition 'Postmodernism, Style and Subversion 1970-1990' is at the V&A Museum in London until the 15th January 2012. Wise up before you go with this overview of the artistic movement that was all about excess, consumer capitalism and children's colours.

The Saliva Milkshake

This imaginatively assembled play was half an hour of political paranoia, beautifully minimalistic setting and quiet yet powerful acting.

Adopting Equality

The first week of November was National Adoption Week, but adopting for same-sex couples is still tainted with prejudice. (Thumbnail credit Photo Credit: jessebucksc)

A Day in the Death of Joe Egg

The barn's interpretation of this sad tale offered strong performances but lacked the poignancy and horror necessary to explore such a sensitive theme.

Thoroughly Modern Millie

Happily Ever After Society's production of Thoroughly Modern Millie is an impressive evening of glamourous 20's entertainment.

Homeless in York

By James Bithell

What's the reality behind our cosy medieval city? Hannah Ellis-Petersen talks to two of York's teens who have been forced to find a home on the streets.

Billy Bragg

By James Bithell

"I'm great, you're shit, do you like my socks?" As summations of pop music today go, few cut through the superficiality of the mainstream quite so effectively
